options: Flags used to identify which CSS files to load.
Small numerical markers generated by the compiler to tell the Virtual DOM exactly what needs to be updated in an element (e.g., just text, or just class).
A way to skip the component lifecycle hooks.
Errors that appear when a template is malformed.
A way to make the app work on older browsers.
The process of moving static Virtual DOM nodes outside of the render function so they are created once and reused across every re-render.
Lifting the state to the parent component.
A method to increase the priority of an API call.
The z-index of the div.
A Patch Flag indicating that only the text content of this div is dynamic.
The version of the Vue compiler used.
The number of children the div has.
A way to organize files in a project.
A structure where dynamic nodes are tracked in a flat array within a 'Block', allowing the diffing algorithm to skip static branches entirely.
A tool for visual debugging.
The tree structure used by CSS Modules.
It restarts the app.
It returns a promise that resolves after the next DOM update cycle has finished.
It speeds up the browser's clock.
It forces the browser to refresh the page.
Parse (turning template string into an AST).
Transform (applying optimizations like hoisting and patch flags).
Generate (creating the final Render Function string).
Hydrate (connecting the DOM to the server state).
A native HTML element.
A Plain JavaScript object that describes what the real DOM element should look like.
A specialized server for Vue apps.
A variable stored in LocalStorage.
Vue downloads a security update.
The old Virtual DOM tree is compared to the new one, and only the necessary changes are applied to the real DOM.
The component is deleted from memory.
The CSS is re-compiled.
A backup copy of the real DOM.
A lightweight JavaScript representation of the DOM that allows Vue to efficiently calculate minimal updates.
A security feature.
A debugging tool.
Flags for debugging.
Compiler hints that tell the runtime which parts of a template are dynamic, enabling faster updates.
Security patches.
Feature flags for experimental features.
